newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Moscow and Chechnya agree on some pipeline details.
newsitem.headline: Moscow and Chechnya agree on some pipeline details.

text.p: Work will begin in the next few days on mending a pipeline to carry Azeri oil across Russia's rebel region of Chechnya to the Black Sea, and Moscow will pay for the work, Interfax news agency said on Saturday.
It quoted Boris Berezovsky, deputy secretary of Russia's policy-making Security Council, as saying Chechen specialists would carry out the work although Russians could be brought in.

"Work on restoring the Chechen part of the Baku-Novorossisk pipeline will be fully financed by the federal authorities," the agency quoted Berezovsky as saying in an interview in the Chechen regional capital Grozny.
He did not give an estimate for how much it would cost.
It quoted the president of the Chechen state oil company YUNKO, Khodzhakhmed Yarikhanov, as saying work would begin on the pipeline "in the next few days".
It was not clear how long the work would take, nor when oil would begin to flow.
The pipeline, a key conduit for Azeri oil from Baku on the Caspian Sea to the Russian Black Sea port of Novorossisk, was damaged during Russia's war with Chechen rebels.
An outline agreement on the pipeline was signed in the Azeri capital Baku on Friday. Saturday's talks were to tackle some of the details.

The deal is significant because Chechnya has set itself up as a de facto independent entity since the war ended last August. The Kremlin regards Chechnya as one of 89 regions within the Russian Federation, although has adopted a pragmatic approach to several bilateral problems.
Officials said earlier the two delegations would also discuss agreements on Russian-Chechen banking and customs ties.

The pipeline deal, held up for months by bickering between the sides over details, is intended to clear the way for crude output from an $8 billion Western consortium developing off-shore Azeri Caspian Sea fields to reach world markets.
Few details of the agreement have been made public.

Radio Ekho Moskvy quoted a Chechen presidential aide on security, Akhmed Zakayev, as saying the agreement did not specify what tariffs Chechnya would get, but he said he did not expect any major further disputes.

"All questions were removed yesterday in the first half of the day in Moscow, and in Baku (Friday evening) we talked over all the nuances," he said. "On the whole, an agreement on all questions has been reached."
Chechen Interior Minister Kazbek Makhashev told Ekho Moskvy a supplementary agreement on tariffs and other details would take another 20 or 30 days.
He said Russian special forces would guard the pipeline.
But Yarikhanov told Interfax Chechen authorities would assume responsibility for the security of any Russian workers brought in to repair the pipeline.
Friday's agreement was signed by Russian Fuel and Energy Minister Boris Nemtsov, Yarikhanov and the president of Azeri state oil company SOCAR.
The consortium, led by British Petroleum Co, wants to begin using the route to transport its oil later this year.
